thread.title: Navarre Raiders keep bouncing back from injuries
thread.title_full: Navarre Raiders keep bouncing back from injuries

title: Navarre Raiders keep bouncing back from injuries
text:
Navarre Raiders keep bouncing back from injuries BRIAN ACHATZ, bachatz@pnj.com 7:19 p.m. CDT October 17, 2015 Injured Michael Carter signing autographs for young Navarre fans. (Photo: Brian Achatz/bachatz@pnj.com) 3 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
One of the biggest keys to success for any football team is staying healthy. 
In prep football, the 10-game regular season can take a toll on teams ... often at unfortunate times. 
And though Navarre started its season without several leaders (due to injury) and later lost two standout players for the remainder of the season (Michael Carter, Aaron Mitchell), the Raiders have remained flexible through the adjustment process. 
Navarre (8-0, 2-0 in District 2-6A) is off to the best start in program history and is fresh off a shutout win over district rival Milton on Friday. Navarre shows great defense in win over Milton 
"It was definitely tough last Friday (vs. Escambia) when Aaron (Mitchell) got hurt," Navarre coach Jay Walls said. "But the credit goes to our kids. They did a good job this week in practice. We had to work some guys at different spots at linebacker, and a couple different guys at running back. We wanted to create some depth and the response by our guys was outstanding." 
Frye appears back to health at Escambia 
Escambia (4-4, 0-2) has dealt with its own injury woes, and to make matters worse, it happened to be the area's second leading rusher â€” Jabir Frye. 
Before suffering an ankle injury two weeks ago at Pine Forest, Frye had carried the ball 80 times for 915 yards and 8 TDs. 
Frye missed Week 7 at Navarre, and no one seemed sure whether or not Jabir Frye would see playing time against Tate.
